qas.question: What did early research show people preferred as a day length?
What was the fault not considered in the early theories of day length?
What did electric lighting in the evening do to the test subjects circadian phase?
When did more stringent testing determine that humans preferred a 24 hour day?
To what is the 24 hours, 11 minutes day outcome of research closest ?
Who prefers a 25 hour day when exposed to stimuli like daylight?
What did the research shield the participants from?
Who was aware of the phase-delaying effect of indoor ekectric lights?
When did testing determine peple preferred a 25 hour day?
Who estimated the human rythem was in perfect sinc with the solar day?

context: Early research into circadian rhythms suggested that <b5_0>most people<b5_0/> preferred a day closer to <a0_0>25 hours<a0_0/> when isolated from external stimuli like daylight and timekeeping. However, this research was faulty because it failed to shield the participants from <a1_0><b6_0>artificial light<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Although subjects were shielded from time cues (like clocks) and daylight, <b7_0>the researchers<b7_0/> were not aware of the phase-delaying effects of indoor electric lights.[dubious – discuss] The subjects were allowed to turn on light when they were awake and to turn it off when they wanted to sleep. Electric light in the evening <a2_0>delayed<a2_0/> their circadian phase.[citation needed] A more stringent study conducted in <a3_0><b8_0>1999<b8_0/><a3_0/> by <b9_0>Harvard University<b9_0/> estimated the natural human rhythm to be closer to 24 hours, 11 minutes: much closer to the <a4_0>solar day<a4_0/> but still not perfectly in sync.
